is  a very small city of only a few thousand people in
. The town is a suburb of

Although there's not much to do around Swartz Creek, many people are happy where they live and crime is minimal.  Swartz Creek is a wonderful place to live if you're ready to retire, but younger people may be better suited to visiting

, forty miles west.

Many living outside the city associated with the city as their mailing address PO is Swartz Creek, they live in the School District of the same name or have a Swartz Creek exchange telephone number.

has two Swartz Creek exits on Miller Road and Morrish Road with two others in the area: on Bristol Road, Flint Township near the airport and on Sheridan Road (M-13), Clayton Township.  Swartz Creek lies west of Flint and east of Durand on the expressway.

value: content=Located right next door just about a mile away.  See

Although Swartz Creek may not be very big, you will still need a car or a good bike to get around. The city's main streets: 2/3 of Miller Road, Seymour and Elms, all have bike lanes.  the state operates a public parking lot on Miller Road east of I-69 on the south side of the road.

value: Genesee County's Mass Transportation Authority's Swartz Creek location offers Your Ride, a public location to location scheduled service.  Rides must be schedule 24 hours in advance.

content=This where you can go gamble and watch horse races. Run year round with races via simulcasting from other locations. The Clubhouse Restaurant seats 480 with reservations are recommended. The Restaurant is open Fridays and Saturdays 5:30pm to approx. 10:00pm during live horse racing.

content=free outdoor concert running from mid-June to early August at an outdoor amphitheater. Concession and hot dog stands on site. Free prize drawings. Bob Smeets Coney Night on the last regularly scheduled night. Two make up nights on Tuesday follow the regular schedule.

content= This event is sponsored by Genesee Wanderers Bicycle Club and is non-competitive bicycle ride that starts in the city at Assenmacher Cycling Center with five different routes from the 20 miles flat to the Century route (100 miles flat to moderate hills). Started in 1980, the ride is held the third Sunday in August and is endorsed by the Governor's Council on Physical Fitness, Health and Sports. Parking available at Swartz Creek Community School including Mary Crapo at 8197 Miller Road
